com.avaya.csta.binding

Class RegisterDevice

  • java.lang.Object
    • ch.ecma.csta.CastorObject
      • com.avaya.csta.binding.RegisterDevice
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class RegisterDevice
extends ch.ecma.csta.CastorObject
implements java.io.Serializable
    THIS REQUEST HAS BEEN DEPRECATED. RegisterTerminalRequest should be used instead.

    Used to register a Terminal for Avaya switches. Registers a specific device with Communication Manager in order to gain shared control or exclusive control over the phone or extension.

    If registering in exclusive control mode and the phone is already logged in or the phone/extension is already registered by your application or another application, your request for registration will supercede any previous registration.

    If registering in shared control mode and the phone is already logged in or the phone/extension is already registered by your application or another application, your request for registration will NOT supercede any previous registration. The phone and the application share control.

    The RegisterDevice request has these parameters:

    RegisterDevice Request Parameters
    device Mandatory Unique identifier of phone/extension.
    loginInfo Mandatory Indicates the information necessary to login or register an extension with Communication Manager. See additional information in the next table.
    localMediaInfo Optional If exclusive mode is selected in the loginInfo parameter, then this option indicates where the device's media stream should be sent (RTP/RTCP address and port), what codecs are preferred, and what packet size is preferred. When in exclusive control mode, the local media information parameter gives you the ability to specify which media mode you want:

    The login information parameters are:

    LoginInfo Parameters
    e911 Not supported
    forceLogin Not supported Login is always forced. That is, even if phone is already logged in or the phone/extension is already registered by your application or another application, your request for registration will supercede any previous registration.
    sharedControl Optional Shared control mode - set to true for shared control or false for exclusive control. Defaults to exclusive control.
    password Mandatory Password assigned to the station during station administration on Communication Manager.
    telecommuterExtension Optional The telephone number of the real telephone that you are directing the media to.

    When in exclusive control mode, the local media information parameter gives you the ability to specify which media mode you want:

    Exclusive Control Media ModesWhen to useWhat to set
    Server media mode Use if also using the Voice Unit Services. Media stream will terminate on connector server. If you wish to use the default codecs and packet size, do not set local media info (let all local media info parameters default). If you want different codecs and/or packet size, then set the codecs and/or packet size, but do not set the RTP/RTCP address.
    Client media mode Use if media stream is to be processed by application. RTP stream can be terminated on any desired machine. Set local media info's RTP/RTCP address to desired IP address and port. May also set preferred codecs and/or preferred packet size.
    Telecommuter media Use when an application wants the media to go to a real telephone. The real telephone can be inside or outside of the Communication Manager domain. Leave out LocalMediaInfo and just set LoginInfo's telecommuterExtension to the telephone number of the real telephone that you are directing the media to.

    The localMediaInfo parameter is of type MediaInfo.

    MediaInfo Parameters
    rtpAddress Optional Specifies the Real Time Protocol address where the media should be directed. Defaults to connector server address so that connector server handles the media. If application wishes to handle the media, then specify an even UDP port address.
    rtcpAddress Conditional Specifies the Real Time Control Protocol address. If no RTP address was specified, then do not specify an RTCP address. If an RTP address was specified, then specify the odd UDP port address that immediately follows the RTP address.
    codecs Optional The preferred set of codecs to be used for media coming to the device and media coming from the device. Possible values are:
    • MediaConstants.G711A (G.711 A-law)
    • MediaConstants.G711U (G.711 Mu-law)
    • MediaConstants.G729
    • MediaConstants.G729A
    • MediaConstants.G723
    Defaults to G.711 A-law and Mu-law, in that order. The G.723 codec may be used only for Client Media Mode (i.e. where the RTP stream is directed to a machine other than the CMAPI connector server and is handled by the application). Multiple codecs can be listed in preferential order. However, a mixture of G.711, G.729 and G.723 cannot be in the list (i.e., the list may contain one or more G.711 codecs or one or more G.729 codecs, but not a mixture of G.711 and G.729). Also, no conversion between G.711 and G.729 (or G.723) is provided by this API. To choose an appropriate codec set, you may wish to first determine how the device's network region and codecs are administered on Communication Manager. This set should consist of only codecs administered for the device's network region.
    packetSize Optional Specifies the size of media packets in milliseconds. Defaults to 20 milliseconds. Possible values are 10-60 in multiples of 10. Recommended to use default. If you don't use default, you must also administer Communication Manager to change the codec of the network region where the phone belongs.
    encryption Optional The preferred set of media encryption schemes to be used for media coming to the device and media coming from the device. Possible values are:
    • MediaConstants.AES
    • MediaConstants.NOENCRYPTION
    Defaults to NOENCRYPTION. Multiple encryption schemes can be listed in preferential order. To choose an appropriate encryption scheme, you may wish to first determine how the device's network region and codecs are administered on Communication Manager. This list should consist of only encryption schemes administered for the device's codec set.

    The RegisterDeviceResponse indicates the request appears valid, and the request is being processed. It provides no useful information and therefore can be ignored.

    Registration is an asynchronous process and can take a relatively long time. For this reason, the result of a registration attempt is not indicated by the response to this request. Rather the registration result is indicated by Terminal Events that are sent. You should request notification of these events prior to the RegisterDevice request. If you do it after, you may not receive the appropriate event (the event may occur before).

    The Terminal Events that may be caused by a RegisterDevice request include:

    • RegisteredEvent
    • RegisterFailedEvent
    If your application will control the media stream, then it will also need to monitor the media events. The Media Events that may be caused by a RegisterDevice request include:
    • MediaStartEvent
    • MediaStopEvent
    Version:
    $Revision$ $Date$

      • getDevice

        public DeviceID getDevice()
        Returns the value of field 'device'. The field 'device' has the following description: The identifier of the device to register. Mandatory.
        Returns:
        DeviceID

      • getLocalMediaInfo

        public MediaInfo getLocalMediaInfo()
        Returns the value of field 'localMediaInfo'. The field 'localMediaInfo' has the following description: The localMediaInfo specifies the client-side media info. That is, the client has the option to specify its (the client's) media info at registration time. If localMediaInfo is not specified (null), then the server will determine all of the local MediaInfo parameters (IP address and ports, default codec(s), preferred packet size).

        If localMediaInfo is not null, then the server will use the non-null parameters specified by the client and determine the rest. For example, if the codec list is specified, but the IP address and ports are null, then the server will use the specified codec list and determine the RTP/RTCP addresses.

        Note: The packet size parameter is just a recommendation for the server. the actual packet size used will depend on CM administration.

        Returns:
        MediaInfo

      • getLoginInfo

        public LoginInfo getLoginInfo()
        Returns the value of field 'loginInfo'. The field 'loginInfo' has the following description: Indicates the information necessary to login or register an extension with Communication Manager. This parameter is of type LoginInfo. Mandatory.
        Returns:
        LoginInfo

      • setLocalMediaInfo

        public void setLocalMediaInfo(MediaInfo localMediaInfo)
        Sets the value of field 'localMediaInfo'. The field 'localMediaInfo' has the following description: The localMediaInfo specifies the client-side media info. That is, the client has the option to specify its (the client's) media info at registration time. If localMediaInfo is not specified (null), then the server will determine all of the local MediaInfo parameters (IP address and ports, default codec(s), preferred packet size).

        If localMediaInfo is not null, then the server will use the non-null parameters specified by the client and determine the rest. For example, if the codec list is specified, but the IP address and ports are null, then the server will use the specified codec list and determine the RTP/RTCP addresses.

        Note: The packet size parameter is just a recommendation for the server. the actual packet size used will depend on CM administration.

        Parameters:
        localMediaInfo - the value of field 'localMediaInfo'.
